comments.author: Марат Яфасов

comments.text:
Just add salt to ice water to make it drop below 0°C.  Colligative 
properties cause a freezing point depression, so the more salt you add, the 
colder it gets until you either melt all of the ice, or saturate the 
solvent.  Throw your beer in there, and it will get cold really fast.﻿

A better way to do it, and works better in large quantities, is to make an 
Ice/salt/water mixture and submerge the beer in the mixture. I learned this 
from my father who happens to be a biochemist, they use this mixture in 
their labs to prevent metallic compounds from igniting in the lab. #science 
#supportivefathers :D﻿

comments.author: Mic Geeboon

comments.text:
I used to do something similar on camping trips. For the record, ice water 
works best(cold of the ice and phase change, while the water allows 
transfer of heat from every inch of surface of the bottle or can). I would 
spin them by hand, using an ice cube like a ball bearing on the bottom so 
it spins with little effort.

With a bit of work, you can use a hand crank and some gears to do 6 at 
once. Then you can do the whole six pack in 60 seconds instead of six 
minutes.﻿
